plan: Initiate with a conservative bid strategy, setting bids slightly above half the value to build baseline data. Gradually introduce riskier tactics by bidding above three-quarters of my value when values are above $70. Experiment with aggressive bids over $80 regardless of competitor behavior, but cautiously observe patterns for adjustment. Gauge opponent tendencies: if recurring high bids exist, consider underbidding or matching their patterns for information. Occasionally adopt an extreme bid to disrupt predictability and gather reactions. Adjust strategy dynamically, reinforcing successful patterns and modifying based on profit analysis and opponent behavior. Aim to optimize by exploiting rivals' tendencies.

In the next round, I'll test an aggressive bidding strategy. I'll bid my value minus a small buffer (e.g., $3-$5) to account for the cost incurred when winning and to target a higher probability of outbidding others. I'll also gather data by adjusting my bid slightly based on past trends of winning and losing bid values. By doing this, I can explore how current bidding behavior of Andy and Charles varies and identify if they underbid or match values closely. This strategy maximizes the chances of winning while minimizing costs for higher profit potential.

Plan: Start by analyzing past bids to identify patterns. Test aggressive strategies when my value is high (>70), bidding slightly above perceived tendencies of Andy and Betty. For medium values (40-69), experiment with bids slightly lower than my value to win competitively without overpaying. For low values (<40), adopt a conservative approach, bidding minimally or not at all to conserve resources and observe other bidders' behaviors. Occasionally, introduce random high bids with low values to gauge their reactions and collect data. Constantly adjust based on profit outcomes and refine strategies after each round to optimize long-term gains.

In the next round, bid around 75% of my value. If my value exceeds 80, consider bidding aggressively near or slightly below the full value. Continuously adjust based on opponents' patterns, introducing occasional high bids to disrupt predictability, while prioritizing maintaining a profit margin.
